The ceremonial pot of boiling water has been removed from the table and, in its place, squatting cross-legged like a tailor, sits the Sabreur. With one hand he holds upright a small, cheaply- bisque doll, with flaxen hair.  It is dressed in a little white slip.  From under the table rim, two dark feminine hands come up to put a white robe on the doll.  The momen this garment has been draped on the little doll, a rada d begins to beat softly in a corner of the room. THE CAMERA DRAWS BACK to reveal that one of the girls who danced in the voodoo ceremony is kneeling before the tabl It is her hands which have dressed the doll.  There are a five people in the room, including the three drummers.  T Sabreur makes magical passes over the doll.
Betsy and Holland are standing in the gateway.  The CAMER POINTED TOWARD the garden.  On the porch in the b.g. we c see Mrs. Rand.
I still can't believe it Paul -- that you wouldn't say a word in your own defense.
I have no defense.  So far as I know -- it is true.
You can't believe that.  You don't know what viciousness it would take to drive a person mad.  You're not vicious or cruel, Paul.

How do you know I'm not?  I was cruel to Jessica.  When I got to know her -- when I found out how empty and ungenerous she was, there was something about her -- something smooth and false -- that made we want to hurt her.
I can understand that.  Everyone feels that way about someone.
No.  It's not just how I felt toward Jessica.  I've been cruel to even you. Besty, smiling, shakes her head. HOLLAND (cont'd)

The first night I saw you -- you were looking at the sea.  You were enchanted -- and I had to break that enchantment.  Do you understand, Betsy -- I had to break it! Betsy is shaken by this, but she tries to put it aside.
You wanted to warn me...
(disregarding her words)
The night you came to me in this room -- to comfort me, to help me -- I turned you away.
Don't, Paul -- don't doubt yourself -- don't make me doubt you.
I remember words I said to Jessica  - words mixed like to poison -- to hurt her, to madden her.
(desperately)
That's past -- that's over and done with...
I want you to be safe, Betsy.  I want to know you're away from this place -- home again, where nothing can harm you -- nothing and no one.
You want that?
Yes. They stand looking at each other in silence.
Mrs. Rand is seated in an easy chair, obviously enjoying interlude of leisure.  Clement comes from the house, brin her a bulky newspaper, still in its mail wrapper.
Would you like to see the paper, Mrs. Rand? (proudly)
This is our newest one.
Thank you , Clement! She takes it and starts slitting the wrapper eagerly.
Betsy and Holland start across the garden to the porch.
Mrs. Rand seems them and waves a section of the paper in welcome.
You're just in time.  Will you join me in the Sunday paper? Betsy and Holland sink into porch chairs, looking gratefu for the shade.  Betsy takes off her hat and tosses it ont the coffee table.
Considering that the paper is three months old and this isn't Sunday -- no thank you.
(smiling)
I guess I'll wait until I'm home, Mrs. Rand. Mrs. Rand looks at a page of rotogravure section.
(casually)
That's a long wait...
I'm afraid not.  Betsy's leaving us, Mother. Mrs. Rand puts down the paper and looks at them, startled HOLLAND (cont'd)
She's decided to go on the next boat.
Why, Betsy -- we can't lose you.  You mean too much to us here.
That's sweet of you, Mrs. Rand.
Betsy feels there is nothing she can do for Jessica...
Rand and Dr. Maxwell come through the gate and walk up th garden path.  As they do so, Mrs. Rand comes down the por steps.  Betsy and Holland follow her.
Dr. Maxwell -- it's nice to see you.
(grimly)
Dr. Maxwell has very unpleasant news for us.
(nervously)
An accident at the mill?
No -- it's about Mrs. Holland.  A result of our discussion the other day, I'm afraid.
What about her?
In view of all the circumstances, the commissioner has decided on a legal investigation.
Investigation of what?
Of the nature of Mrs. Holland's illness.  And, of course, the events which led up to it.
In other words, I'm on trial.
I did everything I could to forestall this, Paul.  I don't think there's any question of your innocence in the matter.  But there's been too much talk.  The thing's out of hand.
Maybe it's better this way, Mother.  I'm glad you're going home, Betsy -- you'll be out of the mess.
But she isn't.  She's been subpoenaed. Holland turns to the Doctor, his face stricken.
Miss Connell's testimony will be very important.
(quietly)
I would have stayed anyway, Dr. Maxwell.
We're all in it.  There won't be a shred of pride or decency left for any of use. (violently)
Say something, Paul!  You've always been good with words.  Put some together, now, and tell us that you're not responsible -- that every damnable bit of it doesn't rest squarely on your shoulders!
You're wrong, Wesley.  The guilt is mine -- all of it.
(bitterly)
Are you going to lie for him, Mother?
Betsy, tell them about the Houmfort.  Tell them what you saw there.
(protestingly)
Mrs. Rand...
You must, Betsy. They'll have to believe you.
(reluctantly)
Mrs. Rand was at the Houmfort that night.  But there's nothing wrong with that.  She's gone there for years -- trying to take care of those people,  to help them.
What do you mean?
I don't understand...
I think I do.   (smiling)
I've often talked a little voodoo to get medicine down a patient's throat.
It's more than that, Doctor.  I've entered into their ceremonies - pretended to be possessed by their gods... They stare at her, dumbfounded. MRS. RAND (cont'd)
But what I did to Jessica was worse than that.  It was when she going away with Wesley.  There was that horrible scene. She turns to Rand. MRS. RAND (cont'd)
You thought she loved you, didn't you?  She didn't.  She didn't love anyone except herself  -- her reflection in the mirror, the look she could bring into a man's eyes.
That isn't true.  You never understood her.
(disregarding his protest)

That night, I went to the Houmfort.  I kept seeing Jessica's face -- smiling -- smiling because two men hated each other -- because she was beautiful enough to take my family in her hands and break it apart.  The drums seemed to be beating in my head.  The chanting -- the lights --  everything blurred together.  And then I heard a voice, speaking in a sudden silence.  My voice.  I was possessed.  I said that the woman at Fort Holland was evil and that the Houngan must maker her a Zombie. Dr. Maxwell has been studying Mrs. Rand with a curious, intent expression.
And what happened then, Mrs. Rand?
(unsteadily)
I hated myself.  I kept saying to myself over and over again that these people had no power; they had no strange drugs; that there is no such thing as a Zombie.
Ah -- that's where reason took hold.
Yes, I said it, and I made myself believe it. But when I got here, Jessica was already raging with fever.

Two things had happened, Mrs. Rand.  One was that your daughter-in-law had been taken ill with a fever.  The other thing -- completely disconnected -- was that you had wished her ill, because she had hurt your sons.
(protesting)
But I had no thought of harming her.  It wasn't I...

You were possessed.  That is true -- possessed by your subconscious mind.  You were in the Houmfort, surrounded by their symbols.  To them, nothing worse can happen to a person than to be made into a Zombie.  Your subconscious mind used their own words for evil.
Dr. Maxwell is right, Mother.
(gently and kindly)

Emotion tricks all of us, Mrs. Rand.  And you are a woman with a very strong conscience.  That conscience has been tormenting you.  The rest is coincidence.  There is no such thing as a Zombie.  The dead do not come back to life.  Death is final. From the hills comes the sound of a single conch, loud an thin. The CAMERA PANS from the group around Mrs. Rand to the to door.  Jessica walks out of it and comes slowly past the fountain.

The CAMERA IS FOCUSED ON a little five-and-ten-cent store doll about three inches high.  It is dressed in a crude imitation of Jessica's loose, belted, white gown.  A thre is tied around it and this thread leads off, taut. The CAMERA PANS ALONG the thread to show us that the othe end of the thread, some twenty feet long, is held by a ne crouched near the altar.  Halfway between this man and th doll, the Sabreur, his sword stuck in the mound before hi straddles the thread, his hands clasped around the thread not touching it.  Carre-Four stands watching. The conch is blowing its strange, magnetic call and the negroes are chanting as they watch the Sabreur and the do The Sabreur makes motions as if he were pulling on the th but still does no touch it.  He makes these motions over over again.  The doll moves slowly.  Then suddenly stops. The Sabreur's most frantic efforts fail to move it.
ANOTHER ANGLE -- Jessica comes slowly past the fountain.

Jessica! She does not seem to hear but continues walking toward th gate.  We hear the sound of running feet.  Holland and Be run up to Jessica.  Holland takes her arm, but she contin to walk forward.  He tries to hold her.  It is apparent h cannot do so without the use of considerable force.

Jessica!  Jessica! She pays no attention but continues to move forward towar the gate.  Betsy, realizing that is something outside of previous experiences with the woman, has the presence of to run forward and slam shut the great wrought-iron gate. Jessica walks up against the gate and stands there, unabl move any further.  They stand and look at her perplexed.

The doll has stopped moving.  The Sabreur is exerting all force.  We can see the sweat soaking his white shirt.  Th others are chanting, louder now, swaying in rhythm with h pulling movements.  The conch is being blown with a more insistent and compelling note.  Still, the doll-figure refuses to move.  The Sabreur stops.  The conches are suddenly silenced.
In this sudden silence, Holland and Jessica look at each other across the motionless figure of Jessica.
The Houmfort -- they're trying to get her back there. Betsy and Holland look at each other.  Then Betsy takes Jessica's arm.
Come with me, Jessica. Obedient again, Jessica allows Betsy to turn her around a lead her back to the open tower door.  As Betsy and Jessi go into the bedroom, the door closes behind them.

The room is in darkness.  In the faint light from the bar windows, we see Betsy sleeping on the chaise lounge.  A shadow moves across her face. Her eyes go quickly to the bed, where the outline of Jessica's figure reassures her.  There is another muffled, dragging sound the tower.  Betsy sits up, listens intently.  She gets up goes toward the door leading into the tower. As if answer to this move, a whispering rustle comes from the screen of bamboo against the tower-wing of the house.  Sh stares toward the bamboo.  She sees nothing. Steeling herself, s moves into it, walking with the slowness of nightmare fea looking from side to side with the slightest possible mov her head.  At the foot of the steps, she turns to look ba at the bamboo.  A distorted shadow slithers out from unde the stalks.  Her panic released, Betsy runs up the steps, down the shadowy porch to the door of Holland's bedroom.
(in a very low, choked cry)

Paul...Paul... She flings herself against the door, turns the handle, an runs into the room, closes the door behind her.  Into the space before the porch steps moves the great gaunt figure Carre-Four.  This is our first full sight of him in the scene.  He is bare to the waist, wearing only a pair of d ragged trousers.  He starts up the steps.

Betsy comes out of the door to Holland's bedroom, followe Holland who has put on a robe.  In a CLOSE SHOT, we see t shock that springs into their two faces as they see Carre Four facing them across the length of the porch, moving toward them, a single slow step at a time.  As Carre-Four sees Betsy's white-clad figure, his hands come up slowly his sides.
You!  What are you doing here? Carre-Four continues his slow, implacable move forward. lifted hands start reaching outward. HOLLAND (cont'd)

Get out of here. Carre-Four comes on relentlessly, his great arms outstret toward Betsy, the enormous hands curving to seize her.  F comes into Holland's face.  With a quick gesture, he pres Betsy back and steps in front of her. HOLLAND (cont'd) (a little uncertainly)
Get out of here -- Carre-Four is almost upon them.  His shoulders press forw as he reaches out.
(quiet, with great authority)

Carre-Four! The single word freezes Carre-Four into immobility.  Astounded, Betsy and Holland turn to see Mrs. Rand at the end of the porch -- her face and hair pale above a dark, like robe. MRS. RAND (cont'd)

Carre-Four.  Go back. Slowly, the giant figure obeys.  Carre-Four turns to face her.  His hands relax, his arms fall to his sides again.  In his blind fashion, Carre-Four moves back across the po turns and goes down the steps to the garden.  Holland, wh has been watching this transfixed, starts after him. MRS. RAND (cont'd)
Paul! Holland pauses at the head of the stairs and turns to her MRS. RAND (cont'd)

Let him go.  Don't touch him, don't try to stop him! Betsy has come down the porch behind Holland and she and Rand stand together.  All three of them look into the gar Carre-Four slips through the gates and is immediately los sight in the darkness of the road beyond.
As Betsy steps into her room, she sees Rand standing by o of the windows.  In his face and his posture are complete dejection, utter misery.
Betsy, can I talk to you a minute?
(with quiet sympathy)
Of course, Wes. She waits, inquiringly.  Rand takes a few steps into the and turns to stare through the door, across the garden to Jessica's room.
Does she suffer?  Does she know what she is?
I don't know. (trying to ease the truth)
I once asked Dr. Maxwell the same question.  He said he thought she was like a sleepwalker who would never waken.
She hated sleep.  She used to say it was a thief -- stealing away her life, an hour at a time...
(trying to speak lightly)

Not to a nurse.  Sleep is a cure. Betsy crosses to the dressing table and takes a small cot stoppered bottle from a drawer.  She pulls out the cotton shakes two little pills into her hand. BETSY (cont'd) (going to Rand)
In fact, I'm prescribing sleep for you right now. She puts them into his hand. BETSY (cont'd)
Be a good patient.  Take these and go to bed.
(suddenly)
She's dead.  The dead ought to be buried.
(gently)
But she's not dead, Wes.
(violently)
You know what she is!  That's death -- no mind, no senses -- no love, no hate, no feeling -- nothing!
Please, Wes, do as I ask.  You must rest, you must sleep. Rand turns his hand and lets the tablets fall to the floo
(dully)
She should have rest. (looking up at Betsy)
She shouldn't have to walk and walk, in that black emptiness. (with realization)
You could set her free.  You could give her rest.  You could give her rest. Betsy, alarmed and troubled, puts her hand on his arm.
Don't think of it, Wes.  I couldn't do that. Rand turns and takes hold of her arm pleadingly, urgently
You could do it.  You have drugs -- it would be so quick -- a single injection.  If you won't do it for her sake, do it for Paul. Betsy shakes her head.
No, Wes.

Jessica was never any good for Paul.  You will be, you are.  And Mother -- seeing Jessica day after day -- never able to escape, never able to forget.  Please, Betsy -- it's only merciful. He looks into her eyes and sees the finality of her refus there.  His hand drops from her arm and he turns away.
(with great pity)
Her heart beats, Wes.  She breathes.  That's life -- I once took an oath to guard life. Rand straightens up and takes a deep breath.
I know.  I shouldn't have asked it. He starts slowly to the open door.
The Houngan and the Sabreur are working over the doll aga It begins to move.

The doll has stopped despite the frenzied efforts of the Sabreur and the wild chanting of the voodoo adepts.  Noth can make it move again.  There is a whispered consultatio between the Sabreur and the Houngan.  The Houngan lifts h hand and the drums begin to beat a light rapid rhythm. With one swift movement, he stabs this through the doll's back.

He looks at her for a long moment and then, as a resolve had formed in his mind, goes to the statue of S Sebastian, takes hold of one of the iron arrows.  He tugs it, but it refuses to come free. The stars seem to have fallen to the surface of the sea. see lights here and there, only a few feet from the water flaring and sparkling.
MED. LONG SHOT.  This is a closer shot of the scene and identifies the lights.  There are torches held in the han of black fisherman, up to their knees in water, spearing flounders by torch light.

With a cry of triumph, he holds aloft a struggling flounder.  He disengages it from spear and puts it into the sack slung from his belt. MED. CLOSE SHOT -- another fisherman.  He, too, is moving stealthily forward, spear poised, torch held low.  Something on the surface of the water near-by attracts hi attention and he lifts up his torch, the periphery of the light widening as he holds it aloft.  The widening light reveals the dead body of Jessica afloat on the surface of water, pallid and dreamlike, her wet, white garments clin like cerements.  The fisherman looks for a moment at the and then calls off to one of the other fishermen. LONG SHOT -- flounder fishermen, their lights all converg on a central light.

The fishermen come in bearing their tragic burdens.  Rand body is carried on the shoulders of four fishermen. Holland, Betsy and Mrs. Rand stand watching the fishermen bringing in the bodies of the dead.  Across the garden fr the fountain stands the little group of house servants al watching. It was a sad time at Fort Holland.  Mother Rand was completely broken by the tragedy. But she's a woman of   courage. She's begun to build up her  life again at St. Sebastian -- It's a good life and a full one.  As for Paul and me -- it wasn't a simple problem for either of us. Sorry to keep you waiting, darling!  I thought I'd never get away.  Invoices and stock lists piling up all day long.  The balmy tropics were never like this.
